perturbation.original_text: 1.19. "Notice of Initial Acceptance of First Product Order" means Integra's acceptance of the Treated Integra Product or Partially Treated Integra Product pursuant to the First Product Order. Such acceptance shall be issued in the form of Attachment C by Integra within ten (10) business days of receipt by Integra or its Affiliates of product (and related quality and testing documentation) meeting specifications mutually agreed upon by Integra and PcoMed.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.19. "Notice of Initial Acceptance of First Product Order" means Integra's acceptance of the Treated Integra Product or Partially Treated Integra Product pursuant to the First Product Order. Such acceptance shall be issued in the form of Attachment C by Integra within one (1) business day of receipt by Integra or its Affiliates of product (and related quality and testing documentation) meeting specifications mutually agreed upon by Integra and PcoMed.
perturbation.explanation: This modification reduces the acceptance period to 1 business day, which is an unreasonably short timeframe that may violate general commercial reasonableness standards and could be deemed an unfair business practice, especially considering the complexity of quality and testing documentation review.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing; Unfair Business Practices

perturbation.original_text: 6.1. Payment Terms and Reports. Payments due under Section 2.2 shall be payable to PcoMed by Integra on a quarterly basis within 45 days following the end of each calendar quarter.
perturbation.changed_text: 6.1. Payment Terms and Reports. Payments due under Section 2.2 shall be payable to PcoMed by Integra on a quarterly basis within 90 days following the end of each calendar quarter.
perturbation.explanation: Increasing the payment timeframe to 90 days after the end of each quarter could be seen as an unfair and unreasonable delay, potentially violating state prompt payment laws if such laws exist for commercial transactions in New Jersey or Colorado (where the parties are located).  This could lead to legal challenges based on breach of contract and violations of fair business practices.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of state prompt payment laws; Breach of Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text: 6.2. Records and Audits. Integra shall keep and maintain accurate records and documentation pertaining to Net Sales of Treated Integra Product in sufficient detail to permit PcoMed to calculate payments due hereunder. Integra shall retain such records and documentation for a period that is consistent with its Records Retention Policy. Such records and documentation will be available for inspection during such period by an independent certified public accountant selected by PcoMed and reasonably acceptable to Integra, solely for the purpose of verifying the payments made by Integra under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 6.2. Records and Audits. Integra shall keep and maintain accurate records and documentation pertaining to Net Sales of Treated Integra Product in sufficient detail to permit PcoMed to calculate payments due hereunder. Integra shall retain such records and documentation for a period of one (1) year. Such records and documentation will be available for inspection during such period by an independent certified public accountant selected by PcoMed and reasonably acceptable to Integra, solely for the purpose of verifying the payments made by Integra under this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the records retention period to one year is inconsistent with standard business practices and potentially conflicts with statutes of limitations for breach of contract claims, which often extend beyond one year (e.g., six years in New Jersey for contract claims). This could hinder PcoMed's ability to effectively audit Integra's records and pursue legal remedies for underpayment or other contractual violations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Conflicts with statutes of limitations for breach of contract claims
